transactions.preamble: The following question is about starting up a new business. Work through the incremental changes in the Accounting Equation for all actions to produce the Financial Statements.

transaction.statement: An individual commences his business on 1 January with £20,000 cash.

equity.preamble: The amount of Owner's Equity signifies the owners claim over the assets of the enterprise. At the conclusion of this action the individual's stake in the business is worth £20,000. This amount is therefore entered on the right-hand side of the equation.

asset.preamble: This is represented on the other side of the equation by a Cash entry of the same amount.

transaction.footnote: This amount balances the Equity sum added above. The accounting equation is essentially the running balance sheet, so both sides must tally. No other entries occur.

transaction.statement: Out of these cash resources he purchases plant and equipment for £12,000.

asset.preamble: From the Cash resources the individual purchases Plant & Equipment for £12,000. Only one side of the equation needs adjustments, namely the Asset side. Remember that the requirement is to enter the INCREMENTAL changes to the equation.
This is balanced by a Cash adjustment used to purchase this asset. This is entered as a negative amount as we record the incremental changes, in this case to the cash available.

transaction.statement: Inventories of raw materials are purchased on credit for £6,000.

asset.preamble: Another asset is acquired --- inventory --- financed by the suppliers of the inventory. Eventually the business will have to pay this amount in cash. Until it does Creditors remain a liability. How much is the owner now worth? Still 20,000, represented by 26,000 of assets less 6,000 owed to his creditors. The incremental changes to the equation are: the asset.

equity.preamble: Eventually these raw materials will be processed into finished goods. They are paid for by Creditors. This is not money in our pockets, but money owed to us.

transaction.statement: £500 worth of inventory is processed through the machines at a labour cost of £20 to form finished goods inventory.

asset.preamble: £500 worth of Raw Material Inventory is processed through the machines to produce Finished Goods Inventory. There is an associated labour cost of £20. This £20 is cash spent on adding value to the Raw Material, all of which the business would hope to recover in the eventual selling price. There are 3 incremental changes: first the cash:

transaction.statement: The accountant, an employee of the business, is paid his wage of £10 in cash.

asset.preamble: The most important employee of the business, the accountant, is paid his wage of £10 in cash. Wages paid to production workers, as in the previous action, increase the value of the inventory to be sold; those of administrative workers do not increase the value of assets or vary with output, so are a charge against profits not yet earned. The incremental change is therefore to the value of the original capital. There are two accounting equation entries. First the cash is reduced:

equity.preamble: ... and similarly the Owner's Equity by the same amount.

transaction.statement: The entire finished goods inventory is sold for £750 on credit.

asset.preamble: The entire finished goods inventory is sold for £750 on credit. The company makes a profit of £230 on this transaction, which in turn increases the Owner's Equity. Debtors --- an Asset --- is created since cash has not been received for the sales. There are therefore 3 incremental changes to the accounting equation: Finished Goods eliminated ....
which are sold on credit, hence creating a debtor to the company.

equity.preamble: Sales should generally result in a profit being recorded. This profit amount is the difference between the value of the Sales and the costs incurred in producing and selling the goods --- COGS. This is done with the following two transactions:

transaction.statement: £3,000 of the amount due to suppliers is paid along with an advertising bill of £10. At this point the machine which has an effective working life of 24,000 hours has been used for 100 hours.

asset.preamble: This is a more complicated action: first the £3,000 paid to the suppliers has two incremental entries - the cash is reduced ...

equity.preamble: and the creditors a paid off in part. Note that paying off creditors is a non-operational cash transaction.

asset.preamble: The advertising bill is also paid in cash (an expense of being in business) and it also reduces the Owner's Equity. The depreciation charge on Plant is 50 for the 100 hours of use; this reduces the value of the plant and the level of Owner's Equity, where it is a Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) item.
